docs.snippet: Should Heath Ledger be named best supporting actor at the Oscars on Sunday, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said the statuette would eventually become the possession of Matilda Rose Ledger, daughter of Ledger and the actress Michel...
docs.lead_paragraph: Should Heath Ledger be named best supporting actor at the Oscars on Sunday, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said the statuette would eventually become the possession of Matilda Rose Ledger, daughter of Ledger and the actress Michelle Williams, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Ledger, who died in January 2008 of an accidental drug overdose, is nominated for his performance in “The Dark Knight.” Posthumous Oscars usually go to a winner’s spouse or oldest child. Mr. Ledger was not married to Ms. Williams, but Matilda, 3, is legally ineligible to sign the contract the academy mandates for all Oscar recipients, which limits their ability to resell the statuette. So, if Mr. Ledger wins, the award will go to Ms. Williams, in trust for Matilda until she turns 18.

headline.main: Heath Ledger Oscar Would Go to Daughter

docs.snippet: Yesterday, the Bagger solicited possible questions that he might crib for carpet duty this Sunday and ended up being hooked up to a firehouse of responses (194 and counting). Apart from the haters, who always punch in when there is a hanging piña...
docs.lead_paragraph: Yesterday, the Bagger solicited possible questions that he might crib for carpet duty this Sunday and ended up being hooked up to a firehouse of responses (200 and counting). Apart from the haters, who always punch in when there is a hanging piñata, there were a number of really thoughtful and/or hilarious queries that could end up in play on Sunday.
docs.abstract: Yesterday, the Bagger solicited possible questions that he might crib for carpet duty this Sunday and ended up being hooked up to a firehouse of responses (194 and counting). Apart from the haters, who always punch in when there is a hanging piñata, there were a number of really thoughtful and/or hilarious queries that could end up in play on Sunday.

headline.main: The Bagger in L.A.: So a Reporter Walks Up to a Celebrity on the Oscars Red Carpet…

docs.snippet: Should Heath Ledger be named best supporting actor at the Oscars on Sunday, his statuette would eventually become the possession of his daughter, Matilda Rose Ledger....
docs.lead_paragraph: Should Heath Ledger be named best supporting actor at the Oscars on Sunday, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said that the statuette would eventually become the possession of Matilda Rose Ledger, the daughter of the late actor and Michelle Williams, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Ledger, who died in January 2008 of an accidental drug overdose, is nominated for his performance in “The Dark Knight.” By academy tradition, posthumous Oscars are generally given to a winner’s spouse or oldest child. Mr. Ledger was not married to Ms. Williams, but Matilda, who is 3, is legally ineligible to sign the contract the academy mandates for all Oscar recipients, which limits their ability to resell the statuette. Hence, if Mr. Ledger wins, the award will be given to Ms. Williams, in trust for Matilda until she turns 18. The academy has not said who would accept the Oscar for Mr. Ledger at the ceremony. A Golden Globe for Mr. Ledger in January was accepted by Christopher Nolan, director of “The Dark Knight.”
docs.abstract: Should Heath Ledger be named best supporting actor at the Oscars on Sunday, his statuette would eventually become the possession of his daughter, Matilda Rose Ledger.

headline.main: An Oscar for Ledger Would Go to His Daughter, Academy Says

docs.snippet: Bill Condon and Laurence Mark sounded exhilarated, if somewhat worn out, when they hopped on the phone with Bagger last night from what they called "the bowels of the Kodak Theater." The Bagger said it sounded as if they were sitting almost precis...
docs.lead_paragraph: Bill Condon and Laurence Mark sounded exhilarated, if somewhat worn out, when they hopped on the phone with Bagger last night from what they called "the bowels of the Kodak Theater." The Bagger said it sounded as if they were sitting almost precisely where he would be on Sunday night.
docs.abstract: Bill Condon and Laurence Mark sounded exhilarated, if somewhat worn out, when they hopped on the phone with Bagger last night from what they called "the bowels of the Kodak Theater." The Bagger said it sounded as if they were sitting almost precisely where he would be on Sunday night.
